title: Black salve ointment leaves man with an inch-wide HOLE in his head | Daily Mail Online
paragraphs: The 55-year-old entered a Brisbane hospital with a large lesion on his right temple after allegedly using Black salve, an alternative medicine ointment.
The man is believed to have been applying the salve for four months and he did not turn to professional medical care until there was a black hole in his head.
Doctors at Princess Alexandra Emergency Department in Brisbane were shocked when the man entered the ward in September last year.
He was using a strong narcotic analgesic used to relieve pain to combat the agony and doctors initially believed they would have to operate.
The ointment, also known as drawing salve, contains sanguinarine derived from bloodroot and is often mixed with zinc chloride, working as a corrosive.
The paste is used on a topical area, moles, scars and sometimes cancer, it destroys skin tissue, leaving being a black scar which later falls off.

Black salves were popular in the early 1900s to treat skin lesions, but have been listed as a 'fake cancer treatment' by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) since 2004, and the organisation is actively trying to ban it in the U.S.
The TGA says it is unaware of any credible, scientific evidence that black salve, red salve or cansema can cure or treat cancer.
However, the warnings have not stopped the widespread use of Black salve in Australia.
I think its used a lot more commonly than we realise, dermatologist Dr Erin McMeniman said.
Patients are often quite secretive about where they get it from, but dermatologists often end up seeing cases where there are major complications.
Most commonly the tumour is not adequately treated and then 12 months later its still growing beneath the scar the cancema [black salve] has produced.

            <div itemprop="articleBody"><h1>Man left with an inch-wide HOLE in his head after using 'quack' ointment to treat skin cancer<br /></h1><ul><li><font style="font-size:1.4em;"><b>Australian, 55, had inch-wide hole in his temple after using 'drawing salve'<br /></b></font></li><li><font style="font-size:1.4em;"><b>Man used Black salve on side of his head for four months</b></font></li><li><font style="font-size:1.4em;"><b>Black salve is used as an 'alternative medicine' for skin lesions </b></font></li><li><font style="font-size:1.4em;"><b>The treatment has been condemned in both U.S. and Australia<br /></b></font></li></ul><p class="author-section byline-plain">By

<a href="/home/search.html?s=&authornamef=Sara+Malm" class="author" rel="nofollow">Sara Malm</a>


</p>

</p>

<br /><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">An Australian man created an inch-wide hole in his head using an ointment he thought would help treat his skin cancer. <br /></font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The 55-year-old entered a Brisbane hospital with a large lesion on his right temple after allegedly using Black salve, an ‘alternative medicine’ ointment.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The man is believed to have been applying the salve for four months and he did not turn to professional medical care until there was a black hole in his head.</font></p><div class="clear"> </div><div class="artSplitter">


    <img id="i-9d7f0e3f" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2014/04/09/article-2600537-1CF534D900000578-73_634x421.jpg" style="display: none" height="421" width="634" alt="Black hole: The 55-year-old man had allegedly been using Black salve, a corrosive 'alternative medicine' treatment condemned by medical professionals, for four months" class="blkBorder img-share"/>
    <noscript>
      <img id="i-9d7f0e3f" src="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2014/04/09/article-2600537-1CF534D900000578-73_634x421.jpg" height="421" width="634" alt="Black hole: The 55-year-old man had allegedly been using Black salve, a corrosive 'alternative medicine' treatment condemned by medical professionals, for four months" class="blkBorder img-share"/>
    </noscript>

<p class="imageCaption">Black hole: The 55-year-old man had allegedly been using Black salve, a corrosive 'alternative medicine' treatment condemned by medical professionals, for four months</p>
</div><p> </p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">Doctors at Princess Alexandra Emergency Department in Brisbane were shocked when the man entered the ward in September last year.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">He was using a ‘strong narcotic analgesic used to relieve pain’ to combat the agony and doctors initially believed they would have to operate.</font></p><div class="related-carousel with-fb health half"
     id="p-21"
     data-track-module="am-related_carousel^related_carousel" data-track-selector=".rotator-panels a:not([class*=external])" data-track-pos="static">

<p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">However, he was sent home to tend to the wound with proper instructions and it healed within three months. <br /></font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The man had admitted to staff he had been applying an alternative medicine to the area, which staff believe was a type of Black salve.<br /></font></p><div class="floatRHS">


    <img id="i-9f510e4e" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2014/04/09/article-2600537-1CF5D0CA00000578-28_306x411.jpg" style="display: none" height="411" width="306" alt="Dangerous: Black salve, made from blood root, has been condemned in several countries" class="blkBorder img-share"/>
    <noscript>
      <img id="i-9f510e4e" src="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2014/04/09/article-2600537-1CF5D0CA00000578-28_306x411.jpg" height="411" width="306" alt="Dangerous: Black salve, made from blood root, has been condemned in several countries" class="blkBorder img-share"/>
    </noscript>

<p class="imageCaption">Dangerous: Black salve, made from blood root, has been condemned in several countries</p></div>
<p> </p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The ointment, also known as drawing salve, contains sanguinarine – derived from bloodroot – and is often mixed with zinc chloride, working as a corrosive.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The paste is used on a topical area, 
moles, scars and sometimes cancer, it destroys skin tissue, leaving 
being a black scar which later falls off.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">Black
 salves were popular in the early 1900s to treat skin lesions, but have been listed as a 'fake cancer treatment' by the U.S. Food and Drug 
Administration (FDA) since 2004, and the organisation is actively trying
 to ban it in the U.S.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">In 
Australia, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) condemned the 
ointments as recently as 2012, although they are not yet banned. </font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">The
 TGA says it is ‘unaware of any credible, scientific evidence that 
black salve, red salve or cansema can cure or treat cancer.’</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">However, the warnings have not stopped the widespread use of Black salve in Australia.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">‘I think it’s used a lot more commonly than we realise,’ dermatologist Dr Erin McMeniman said.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">‘Patients
 are often quite secretive about where they get it from, but 
dermatologists often end up seeing cases where there are major 
complications.</font></p><p><font style="font-size:1.2em;">‘Most 
commonly the tumour is not adequately treated and then 12 months later 
it’s still growing beneath the scar the cancema [black salve] has 
produced.’</font></p><div class="clear"> </div><p> </p><p></p><p> </p>
					
<div class="clear"> </div></div>

    DM.later('bundle', function(){

        var taboola_counter = 0;

        var addTaboola = function (node){
            var id = "taboola-stream-thumbnails-" + (++n);
            var taboola_node = '<div id="' + id + '" style="min-height: 280px;"></div>';
            $(node).before(taboola_node);

            window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
            _taboola.push({
                mode: 'thumbnails-b',
                container: id,
                placement: "Stream Thumbnails " + n});
        };

        DM.has('infinite-list', 'InfiniteList', {
url: '/api/infinite-list.html?channelShortName=health&pageSize=10',
            total: 13.0,
            from: 0,
            onAfterAppend: function (container){
                var items = $(container).children('div');
                if(!taboola_every_n){
                    return;
                }

                items.each(function (){
                    if (taboola_counter == 0){
                        addTaboola(this);
                        taboola_counter = taboola_every_n - 1;
                    }
                    else {
                        taboola_counter--;
                    }
